inlineContent.text: Learn how to integrate real-time Parse LiveQuery subscriptions with SwiftUI for reactive, data-driven user interfaces.
This tutorial shows you how to use LiveQuery’s
type as a SwiftUI view model with

to automatically update your UI when data changes on your Parse Server. You’ll build an interactive SwiftUI view that displays real-time updates from GameScore objects, perfect for creating live dashboards, chat interfaces, and collaborative apps.
This tutorial assumes you have already completed
and
tutorials. If you haven’t initialized the Parse SDK yet, please refer to the “Initialize Parse and check server health” section in
. LiveQuery must be enabled on your Parse Server for these features to work.
Start by importing the necessary frameworks for using Parse LiveQuery with SwiftUI.

You’ll need ParseSwift for LiveQuery functionality and SwiftUI for building reactive user interfaces. The combination allows you to create data-driven views that automatically update when your Parse data changes.
These three frameworks provide all the necessary components for creating reactive SwiftUI views with LiveQuery subscriptions.
Import Foundation, ParseSwift, and SwiftUI frameworks.
Create the ParseObject model that will be used with LiveQuery and SwiftUI.
Just like in the LiveQuery tutorial, you need a custom struct conforming to
. This model will be the data type for your subscription and the objects displayed in your SwiftUI views.
Include the required Parse properties and your custom fields. Set default values where appropriate, such as
defaulting to 0.
Create a
struct that conforms to
The merge method helps ParseSwift efficiently update objects when receiving LiveQuery events, improving performance when your SwiftUI view re-renders.
Implement a custom
method for optimal performance.
This preserves the memberwise initializer while providing convenient ways to create GameScore instances.
Add custom initializers in an extension.
Define a query that will be used to subscribe to real-time updates.
Create a query with constraints just as you would for normal fetching. This query will determine which objects trigger events in your SwiftUI view.
This query will match GameScore objects that have fewer than 11 points, and your subscription will receive events when matching objects are created, updated, or deleted.
Create a query for GameScore objects with points less than 11.
Create a SwiftUI view that uses a LiveQuery subscription as its view model.
The
type can be used with SwiftUI’s
property wrapper, making it a perfect view model that automatically triggers view updates when LiveQuery events occur.
Use the
type as a
property. This makes SwiftUI automatically re-render the view whenever the subscription receives events or changes state.
Create a basic SwiftUI view with a
subscription.
Use the
and
properties to show different UI based on the subscription state. This provides feedback to users about the connection status.
Add subscription state checks to the view.
Check for events using the
property and use a switch statement to handle the five event types:
, and
. Each event provides the affected object.
Handle LiveQuery events in the view body.
Include helpful text to guide users on how to see the LiveQuery in action by updating objects in the Parse Dashboard.
Add instructions for users to test the subscription.
Include a button that calls the query’s
method, allowing users to manually stop receiving updates. Notice the use of
to handle the async operation.
Add an unsubscribe button for user control.

tasks.title: Build a SwiftUI view with LiveQuery

inlineContent.text: Subscribe to the query and set up your SwiftUI view with the subscription.
Before your view can display live updates, you need to subscribe to the query and pass the resulting
object to your SwiftUI view. This is typically done at app startup, after initializing the Parse SDK.
Make sure you have initialized the Parse SDK before subscribing to queries. See
for details on initializing ParseSwift with your application ID, client key, and server URL.
Use an async function marked with
to subscribe to the query. The
method returns a
object that can be passed to your SwiftUI view’s initializer.
Create a function to subscribe and initialize the view.

Combine all the components: model definition with merge method, query creation, SwiftUI view with event handling, and subscription setup. The example shows how to create the ContentView with the subscription and use it with a hosting controller in your app. Remember to initialize ParseSwift first (see
Put it all together in a complete example.
Learn how to test your SwiftUI LiveQuery integration and see real-time updates in action.
To verify your implementation works correctly, you’ll use the Parse Dashboard to create, update, and delete GameScore objects, then observe how your SwiftUI view automatically updates in real-time.
Build and run your app. The view should initially show “Subscribed to query!” indicating the LiveQuery connection is active.
If you see “Not subscribed to a query” or an error, verify that LiveQuery is enabled on your Parse Server and that your query was created correctly.
Run your SwiftUI app on a simulator or device.
Navigate to your Parse Server’s dashboard and find the GameScore class in the data browser.
Make sure you’re looking at the correct Parse Server instance that your app is connected to.
Open Parse Dashboard in a web browser.
In the Parse Dashboard, add a new row to the GameScore class. Set the
field to a value less than 11 (like 5 or 8). Set the
field to any string. Watch your SwiftUI app - it should immediately display “Created with points: 5” (or whatever value you entered).
Create a new GameScore object with points less than 11.
In Parse Dashboard, click on the GameScore object you just created and change the
value to a different number less than 11. Save the changes. Your app should now show “Updated with points: [new value]” as the subscription receives the update event.
Update the object to trigger an update event.
Change points to exceed the query threshold. Update the
value to 15 (greater than 11). This makes the object no longer match your query constraint. Your app should display “Left with points: 15” as the subscription receives a
event indicating the object no longer matches the query.

Test the unsubscribe functionality. Tap the “Unsubscribe” button in your app. The view should change to display “Unsubscribed from query!”. Now try creating or updating GameScore objects in Parse Dashboard - your app should no longer receive updates, confirming the unsubscribe worked correctly.
Follow these recommendations for building robust, performant SwiftUI apps with LiveQuery.
Understanding these patterns will help you avoid common pitfalls and create better real-time user experiences.
Use
for subscription ownership. Always use
(not
) when the view creates and owns the subscription. This ensures SwiftUI doesn’t recreate the subscription on every view update.
Implement proper error handling. Wrap subscription calls in do-catch blocks to handle potential errors gracefully. Display error messages in your UI to help users understand connection issues.
Consider subscription lifecycle management. Unsubscribe when views are dismissed or when users navigate away. This prevents memory leaks and reduces server load. You can use SwiftUI’s
modifier to unsubscribe automatically.
Always implement the

method on your ParseObject models when using LiveQuery. This significantly improves performance by allowing faster object updates when events arrive. Without merge, ParseSwift has to fully re-decode objects. With merge, only changed fields are processed.
Optimize with the merge method.
Use field selection for better performance. If you only need specific fields in your UI, use the
method on your query to reduce network traffic and parsing overhead.

Handle reconnection scenarios. Network connections can be interrupted. Consider implementing reconnection logic and showing connection status in your UI to provide a better user experience during network issues.
